title: Invalid Concepts

articles.content: The formation of introspective concepts follows the same principles as the formation of extrospective concepts. A concept pertaining to consciousness is a mental integration of two or more instances of a psychological process possessing the same distinguishing characteristics, with the particular contents and the measurements of the action’s intensity omitted—on the principle that these omitted measurements must exist in some quantity, but may exist in any quantity (i.e., a given psychological process must possess some content and some degree of intensity, but may possess any content or degree of the appropriate category).

No concept man forms is valid unless he integrates it without contradiction
into the total sum of his knowledge.
articles.attribution:
Galt’s Speech,
For the New Intellectual, 126

acknowledgement:
“Definitions,”
Introduction to Objectivist Epistemology, 49
